Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: A Data Reduction Tool for iSHELL
Award.AbstractNarration:
Modern astrophysical instrumentation presents a challenge inherent in the very wealth of data it is capable of producing: sophisticated software is needed to complement the hardware, in order to understand what the data mean in a reasonable length of time. Good data reduction tools, or programs, can be as important to research success as the instruments they support. One new instrument is iSHELL, an exciting near-infrared spectrograph at the IRTF (Infrared Telescope Facility), a 3-meter telescope on Mauna Kea, in Hawaii. iSHELL will receive through this project a data reduction and analysis tool that will be a modification of a highly successful software package proven on the earlier-generation version of this spectrograph.

iSHELL will replace CSHELL, a single-order echelle spectrograph. CSHELL achieved first light in 1993; despite its age and small simultaneous wavelength range (about 0.006 microns at 2.2 microns), CSHELL still averages about 15% of available telescope time because it is one of only a few 1-5 micron echelle spectrographs of comparable resolution available to observers in the northern hemisphere. Capitalizing on technological developments in spectrograph gratings and infrared arrays, iSHELL will provide greatly improved capabilities over CSHELL. CSHELL will have up to 50 times the single-shot wavelength grasp of iSHELL, with up to twice the resolving power (R=70,000). iSHELL has a very strong core science case ranging from planetary atmospheres and comets, to protostellar disks and stellar physics. A wide variety of other science is also enabled with iSHELL's general-purpose capabilities. However, to fully exploit this capability requires the planned data reduction system to efficiently reduce and calibrate complicated cross-dispersed data format.

The IRTF serves a broad community of scientists at major research centers, universities, and small colleges, with substantial student involvement. The earlier generation of software has been used on data from several major instruments, and the same is expected to be true for the software developed under this award.

Funding for this project is being provided by NSF's Division of Astronomical Sciences through its Advanced Technologies and Instrumentation program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NASA Infrared Telescope Facility (IRTF) is a 3-m diameter telescope sited near the 4,200-m summit of Maunakea on the island of Hawaii. The IRTF’s main role is to support NASA’s planetary spaceflight missions and to support NASA’s planetary science objectives in general. It also plays a major role in characterizing potentially hazardous asteroids. In addition, through a memorandum of understanding between NASA and NSF, IRTF is also used to observe astronomical objects outside the solar system. Observing time on IRTF is open to all suitably qualified people (usually PhD astronomers and their students), through an independent proposal review process.

iSHELL is an infrared spectrograph covering the wavelength range of 1-5 microns at high resolving power (R £ 80,000). iSHELL is designed to analyze the atmospheres of planets, comets and stars by measuring the strength of atomic and molecular features in their spectra. The spectrograph was funded by NSF and NASA in 2008 and successfully achieved first light on IRTF in 2016.

Typical raw data output from iSHELL is shown in Figure 1. This needs to be converted into a plot of signal intensity versus wavelength (a spectrum), an example of which is shown in Figure 2. The spectrum can then be analyzed and scientific conclusions made. Astronomers call this process ‘data reduction’. The subject of this report is the iSHELL Data Reduction Tool. This is an interactive software package that takes raw images like those shown in Figure 1 and converts them into publication quality spectra like that shown in Figure 2 (an M6 III cool giant star showing absorption features due to CO gas in the star’s atmosphere). The computer code is written in the IDL language and includes a graphical user interface (GUI) for astronomers to fine tune the process. The code itself is approximately 100,000 lines long.

The code performs a variety of functions. It fixes imperfections in the light-sensing chip, linearizes the signal, adjusts the signal for areas of different sensitivity on the chip (‘flat fielding’), sums up the signal along columns, performs wavelength calibration using lamps emitting light of known wavelengths, and joins the different traces together into one spectrum. In addition, the code uses stars of known spectral shape to remove features (‘telluric’ features) that appear in the astronomical spectra due atoms and molecules in the earth’s atmosphere and that might otherwise be confused with real features in objects themselves.

The data reduction tool itself is a modified version of Spextool, which was constructed for an earlier IRTF lower-resolution spectrograph (SpeX). NSF funded the modification of Spextool for iSHELL. Spextool is freely available by download from the IRTF website. The code can be modified and applied to other spectrographs. Spextool reduces the time for producing publishable quality spectra from days to about one hour for an individual object.
